description: From Middle English honourable, from Old French honorable, honurable, from Latin honōrābilis, from honōrō (“I honour”); cognate with Italian onorabile, Spanish honorable. Surface analysis is honor +‎ -able.

adjectives.description: honorable (comparative more honorable, superlative most honorable) (American spelling)

entries.meaning: (politics) A courtesy title, given in Britain and the Commonwealth to a cabinet minister, minister of state, or senator, and in the United States to the president, vice president, congresspeople, state governors and legislators, and mayors.
A politician or other person who bears the title of "honorable".
examples: These included a reception for the Congress participants, given by the city of Barcelona in a 14th century palace, with guards making room for the mayor and other honorables,  […]
